title: 103_hr509
content: The "Health Freedom Act of 1993" is also known as the "Health Freedom Act." It provides definitions for key terms used in the Act. The "Health Freedom Act of 1993" provides definitions for key terms, including 'dietary supplement' and 'drug' under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. A dietary supplement is defined as an article intended to supplement the diet with vitamins, minerals, herbs, or similar nutritional substances, and is not considered a drug solely based on potency or labeling. The "Health Freedom Act of 1993" defines dietary supplements and drugs under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. A substance in a dietary supplement is not considered a food additive if it is identified in the labeling as a supplement provided by the product. SEC. 413. LABELING AND ADVERTISING OF DIETARY SUPPLEMENTS. The labeling and advertising of dietary supplements allows for truthful and non-misleading claims about the relationship between the supplement and a disease or health-related condition, as long as there is scientific evidence to support it. The Secretary is prohibited from requiring prior approval or regulation of such claims. The Secretary must approve or conform to regulations before using any claim or information related to dietary supplements. Manufacturers can take legal action in a US district court to challenge assertions of non-compliance with labeling regulations. The absence of certain actions regarding assertions does not imply validity. Section 403(r)(5) of the Act is amended by removing clause (D).
